awd_abstract_narration:
National calls to improve undergraduate biology education have advocated for widespread engagement of students in research. Undergraduate researchers report gains in their ability to think and work like scientists and increased interest in and enjoyment of science. They are also more likely to pursue further education and careers in science and research, which drive the nation's progress and economic prosperity. Yet, research experiences are typically structured as internships, which limits the number of students who can participate. In response, colleges and universities have begun to transform their laboratory courses into scalable research experiences, called Course-based Undergraduate Research Experiences (CUREs). Students who participate in CUREs achieve many of the same gains as students who participate in research internships, but there are colleges and universities that have yet to integrate CUREs into their undergraduate curricula - especially colleges and universities that enroll significant proportions of students from under-represented and under-served backgrounds. The CURE Network 2 (CUREnet 2) will take a multi-pronged approach to build capacity for CUREs at Historically Black Colleges & Universities (HBCUs) and other under-resourced colleges and universities. As a result, broader and more diverse populations of students will have access to research experiences. CUREnet 2 will also support networking and collaboration to understand what makes CUREs effective for student learning and development and to maximize the effectiveness, impact, and long-term sustainability of CURE instruction.

CUREnet 2 aims to support the national shift in undergraduate lab instruction toward student engagement in research. CUREnet 2 is designed in response to educational needs and according to theories of change in higher education, thereby maximizing its likelihood of impact and success. With leadership representing seven universities and colleges, including four HBCUs, CUREnet 2 will build national capacity for CURE instruction by: (1) Offering campus-based faculty professional development on CURE instruction; (2) Supporting the development of cross-institution CUREs and acquisition of resources needed to support undergraduate research; (3) Convening meetings to synthesize research in education, cognitive science, psychology, and learning sciences to understand how CUREs influence student learning and development and to plan collaborations to develop needed assessment frameworks, methods, and tools; (4) Convening meetings to identify problems and solutions for sustaining CUREs over time; (5) Improving the functionality, sustainability, and widespread use of the CUREnet website; and (6) Sharing information and resources among CURE-related networks. Ultimately, CUREnet 2 will help ensure the availability and effectiveness of research opportunities for a broad and diverse population of undergraduates early enough to make a difference in their academic and career trajectories.

This project is being jointly funded by the Directorate for Biological Sciences and the Directorate for Education and Human Resources, Division of Undergraduate Education as part of their efforts to address the challenges posed in Vision and Change in Undergraduate Biology Education: A Call to Action (http://visionandchange.org/finalreport/). This project is also co-funded by the Division of Human Resources Development (HBCU-UP) in the EHR directorate.

por.por_cntn:
U.S. higher education has recognized the need to improve undergraduate science instruction in order to prepare the next generation of science researchers to tackle pressing global problems. Engagement in science research at the undergraduate level not only enhances student success in college and in STEM, and it prepares students to make informed career choices. In addition, undergraduate research experiences equip students with key scientific competencies such as the ability to pose hypothesis, design and conduct investigations, analyze data, troubleshoot, and base conclusions on scientific evidence. However, faculty-mentored research internships simply cannot be offered at the scale necessary to ensure that all science majors have an opportunity to engage in undergraduate research. This opportunity gap is especially acute among community colleges as well as other colleges and universities that enroll a majority of students from historically marginalized or minoritized groups.

The undergraduate science education community is addressing this opportunity gap by redesigning science courses to include research experiences, what are known as “course-based undergraduate research experiences” or CUREs. CUREs make it possible for all students who take a course to engage in research, developing their scientific competencies and building their awareness of whether a science research career is the right fit for them.

This project, titled Course-based Undergraduate Research Experiences Network 2 (CUREnet2), built substantial national capacity for CURE instruction, especially among Historically Black Colleges and Universities (HBCUs) and under-resourced colleges and universities. Specifically, CUREnet2:

  • designed and facilitated professional development for >700 science faculty across the US to design and teach CUREs;
  • offered CURE professional development designed by and for HBCUs and community colleges, and implemented in HBCU and community college venues;
  • supported faculty and administrators at diverse institutions in analyzing and revising policy to support, incentivize, and reward CURE instruction; and
  • facilitated knowledge sharing and community building related CURE instruction through a robust, multi-phase development of the CUREnet website, which is home to information about CUREs, examples of CUREs, profiles of institutions that have sustained CURE instruction, and other community-focused resources (e.g., listserv, newsletter, social media).

CUREnet2 has multiple intellectual merits that enabled it to achieve outcomes far beyond its original goals. First, CUREnet2 is physically distributed, meeting faculty and administrators in their own institutional contexts in order to facilitate the process of CURE adaptation and adoption. Second, CUREnet2 has prioritized capacity building by working with teams of faculty at diverse institutions, rather than single individuals. Third, CUREnet2 has integrated structural changes into its work, helping faculty and administrators consider how to change policies and practices that catalyze CURE development and sustainability. Finally, CUREnet2 is multi-faceted; the network has offered professional development, instructional materials, design principles, and information sharing. This structure has enabled diverse audiences to engage in a way that suits their needs, interests, and priorities.

CUREnet2 has had multiple broad impacts. CUREnet2 has engaged faculty across the country in designing and teaching CUREs, thereby massively scaling up access to undergraduate research experiences. The CUREnet2 website has made resources and lessons learned widely and freely available. The site has a robust user pool, with ~10,000 visitors and ~30,000 visits per year for six plus years. More than 260 articles in Google Scholar mention CUREnet, citing the network as an “important online resource” and a place for instructors to share the CUREs they have developed. Although CUREnet started in the life sciences, its community and impact now include many science disciplines (chemistry, physics, geoscience, computer science, statistics), including social sciences (psychology, anthropology, emergency management) and engineering. In sum, CUREnet has become the “go to” resource for instructors seeking to broaden access to undergraduate research as a means to support undergraduates in developing their science competencies and making decisions about pursuing research-related careers.
